reasoning: The critique targets the sailing-to-an-island analogy used in the introduction. However, this analogy is explicitly a framing device—the paper immediately breaks it into three components and then spends the entire essay analyzing component (1) through detailed philosophical and mathematical argument. The analogy is not load-bearing; the arguments about multiplicative value, moral catastrophes, bounded vs unbounded views, etc. stand entirely independently of the metaphor. Even if the metaphor were misleading, removing it would not weaken any substantive conclusion. So centrality is very low. The critique's claim that the metaphor 'assumes a fixed, static target' has some surface correctness—islands don't move—but the paper explicitly acknowledges that values and moral views are uncertain and evolving (Section 2.5 on hedonic treadmill effects, Section 3 on moral uncertainty). The paper doesn't actually rely on the target being fixed; it argues the target is narrow under many possible moral views. The critique also claims the paper needs 'more nuanced models of moral and social progress' but the paper already provides highly nuanced technical analysis of value functions, bounded vs unbounded views, and intertheoretic comparisons. The critique is essentially attacking a pedagogical illustration rather than the substance, and the concern it raises (evolving values, feedback loops) is already addressed in the paper. The phrase 'reference class failure' adds some rhetorical weight but doesn't constitute a substantive argument. Strength is very low because even fully granting the critique, essentially none of the paper's arguments are undermined.
title: The eutopia analogy exhibits reference class failure
